label: Letter 1 from Gertrude Sanford Legendre, January 11, 1943
description: Letter from Gertrude Legendre to her husband, Sidney Legendre, regarding how much she dislikes Washington, news of friends and family, and telling a story of Miss Evans fetching a ham from a friends house with the use of a baby carriage.

metadata.label: Description
metadata.value: Letter from Gertrude Legendre to her husband, Sidney Legendre, regarding how much she dislikes Washington, news of friends and family, and telling a story of Miss Evans fetching a ham from a friends house with the use of a baby carriage.

metadata.label: Transcript
metadata.value:
Lt. Sidney Legendre U.S.N.R.
P.O.166
Nay Yard - Pearl Harbor
T. of HAWAII.
Mrs Sidney Legendre
1528 31st Street N.W.
Washington D.C.
Jan- 11 1943
Dear Sidney, 
I sent you my letter No 55 to-day so it will be interesting for you
you to see how long my No I.V. letter takes to reach you by comparison.
Try writing me this way as the air mail has been discontinued and this will
fill in the long lapses when we get no boat mail.
I am enjoying your flowers my darling which arrive regularly every
week end.They are lovely,and such a delicious thought and bearer of your love.
I am so happy Old Man Morris is picking up his health on Vitamin
pills.They may make his hair grow,and get him back on this tennis court with
you besides.
I dream of those lovely beches, and blue sky,and long to be with 
you splashing in the surf. Here the sun never shines and the ground is covered
in ice and snow. You are so lucky,and I am so happy for you.
Life goes on as usual on its round of office life which leaves
little of interest to report to you in the way of amusement.
I am over one of my colds, and the baby has escaped one all to-
gether. Most people have"flu," many are learning to use their legs and walk as
cars may only be used to go to work with. I assure you that is one thing I
do not mind at all. I only wish I found time for more exercise,and could
join you at the outrigger club for a good burn and a long swim. I miss the
air, exercise, trees and most of all of course you my darling. I live for the
day of your return.
My boss is going away for good across the ocean and we shall miss
him so much. No one could be nicer to work for than David and I am truly
sunk about it.
Take care of yourself my darling and write me often. I live for your
letters. Your last was no 46 received the sixth of Jan.
Please snd me some snap shots,I should love ot have some.
Everything is fine here and going well, and I hope you and Morris
are happy and well too. Write me all your news.
Give Morris my love and tell him Nancy and I both sent flowers
to Mr. Palmer's funeral for you both.
All my love as always- and a big hug and so many kisses.
Armant arrives tomorrow and will telephone you.
I hope your plans have not changed and that all is well with you.
The moon is full [ton]ight and I can picture how beautiful it
must be out in Hawaii shining on the cocoanut palms. How I would love to be
there beside you drinking in the soft night air and living it with you.
Goodnight my darling-
Gertie
